| known_for = | notable_works = }} {{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} '''Edgar Fitzgerald Gordon''' (20 March 1895 – 20 April 1955), born in [[Trinidad & Tobago]], was a physician, parliamentarian, civil-rights activist<ref>Rosemary Jones, [http://www.moed.bm/Documents/Teachers%20Resource.pdf ''Bermuda: Five Centuries'', Chapter 18: Growing Pains], Ministry of Education, Bermuda, 2011.</ref> and labour leader in [[Bermuda]], and is regarded as the "father of trade unionism" there:<ref>[http://www.bpsu.bm/our-history "Our history"], website of Bermuda Public Services Union – BPSU.</ref> "he championed the cause of Bermudian workers and fought for equal rights for black Bermudians, thereby laying the groundwork for much of the political and social change that came about after his death".<ref name=BermudaBiogs>Meredith Ebbin, [http://www.bermudabiographies.bm/Biographies/Biography-DrGordon.html "Dr. Edgar Fitzgerald Gordon, March 20,1895 – April 20, 1955 – Physician, parliamentarian and labour leader"], Bermuda Biographies.</ref> He was president of the [[Bermuda Industrial Union]] (BIU) 1945–55.<ref name=BIU>[http://www.biu.bm/#!about/cjg9 Bermuda Industrial Union website.]</ref> Gordon has been described as "perhaps the only black charismatic leader to have emerged in the island's modern political history",<ref>Frances Henry (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=CGvwGIVkIAQC&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=%22+dr+e.f.+gordon%22&source=bl&ots=d24Fgia9pz&sig=SxLVCqlVpq6rJOtNQ9MMoOlaOWY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=y0ofVM-cAcLvaPzegMAF&ved=0CKYBEOgBMB0#v=onepage&q=%22%20dr%20e.f.%20gordon%22&f=false ''Ethnicity in the Americas''], Walter de Gruyter, 1976, p. 67.</ref> and as "Bermuda's most dedicated Pan-Africanist".<ref>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20150905/ISLAND/150909819&template=mobileart "The unforgettable day I met the Queen"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 7 September 2015.</ref>
In 2011, Gordon was honoured as a National Hero of Bermuda.<ref name=Hero /> Other posthumous honours he has been accorded include the Peace & Social Justice Award 2016 from the Roman Catholic Church of Bermuda.<ref name=PSJA>[http://bernews.com/2016/10/peace-social-justice-award-dr-e-f-gordon/ "Peace & Social Justice Award: Dr. E. F. Gordon"], ''Bernews'', 24 October 2016.</ref>
==Early years and education==
Edgar Fitzgerald Gordon was born to Olympia Jardin and Frederick Charles Gordon in [[Port of Spain, Trinidad]], where he received his early education at [[Queen's Royal College]] (QRC),<ref>[[Tony Martin (professor)|Tony Martin]], ''The Progress of the African Race Since Emancipation and Prospects for the Future'', The Majority Press, 1998, p. 8.</ref> graduating as one of the school's most brilliant scholars.<ref name=Philip2015>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20150321/ISLAND/150329948 "Remembering Mazumbo, a dynamic freedom fighter"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 21 March 2015.</ref> In 1912 he went to [[Scotland]] to study medicine at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. There he met and married a fellow medical student, Clara Christian (who had previously studied music in the US at [[Hampton Institute]] in [[Hampton, Virginia]], and [[Oberlin College]], [[Ohio]]).<ref name=BermudaBiogs /><ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110616/ISLAND11/706149914/-1 "Dr EF Gordon – fought tirelessly for equal rights for black Bermudians"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 16 June 2011.</ref> To the displeasure of her father George James Christian, a Dominican barrister who had settled in the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] in 1902,<ref>[http://www.thedominican.net/articles/christian.htm "George James Christian: Pioneer in Africa"], TheDominican.net, Volume No. 1, Issue No. 32, 27 November 2002.</ref> she abandoned her medical studies to begin a family with Gordon.<ref name=BermudaBiogs/><ref>[http://www.whodoyouthinkyouaremagazine.com/episode/moira-stuart "Moira Stuart", ''Who Do You Think You Are? Magazine''.]</ref>
==Medical career==
Qualifying as a doctor at the age of 23 in 1918, Gordon was for some time a medical practitioner in the small Scottish town of [[Kingussie]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/whodoyouthinkyouare/past-stories/moira-stuart.shtml "Moira Stuart", ''Who Do You Think You Are?'', BBC.]</ref> In 1921 he returned to the Caribbean with his wife and young family. He briefly worked in Trinidad, then went on to become chief medical supervisor in [[Dominica]].<ref name=BermudaBiogs />
===Move to Bermuda=== In 1924, Gordon went to Bermuda, where he would set up a busy medical practice on Heathcote Hill in [[Somerset, Bermuda|Somerset]].<ref name=BermudaBiogs /> According to biographer Ira Philip, Gordon "was brought to Bermuda by [[Sandys Parish|Sandys]] businessman William Robinson to fill a void caused by the death of black Dr Arnold Packwood. The all white local medical board was embarrassed when Dr Gordon passed what he termed was an impossible examination which he contended was calculated to fail him."<ref>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130309/ISLAND09/703099993 "Dr Olivia Tucker — pioneering pharmacist denied the opportunity to work in her homeland"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 8 March 2013.</ref>
Gordon began to take up the cause of black nurses and the discrimination they faced in employment in Bermuda, writing a series of letters dating from 1929 to the editor of ''[[The Royal Gazette (Bermuda)|The Royal Gazette]]'' criticising the refusal of the Bermuda Welfare Society to hire Blacks as district nurses.<ref name=BermudaBiogs /><ref name="Bernews Profile" /> After decades of lobbying, the first black district nurse to be hired was Leonie Harford in 1963.<ref name=BermudaBiogs />
==Political life==
After standing unsuccessfully for Parliament in 1933 and 1943,<ref>Eva N. Hodgson, ''Second Class Citizens; First Class Men'', 2nd edition, Bermuda: The Writers Machine, 1988, p. 67.</ref> Gordon won a seat in [[St. George's, Bermuda|St George's]] in 1946.
===Name change=== On 22 June 1947,<ref name=100Facts>''Mazumbo: 100 Facts and Quotes by Dr. E. F. Gordon'', Writers' Machine, 1994, pp. 14, 33.</ref> in protest at the fact that his fellow parliamentarians persistently refused to address him by his correct title, and that a Bermuda newspaper, the ''[[Mid-Ocean News]]'', prefixed "Mr." to the names of white members of Bermuda's Parliament (second oldest in the world), but called him simply Gordon,<ref name=100Facts /> he announced that henceforth he was to be known by the African name of '''Mazumbo''', with no prefix.<ref name=BermudaBiogs /> His notice to this effect in ''The Royal Gazette'' read: :"I, Edgar Fitzgerald Gordon, Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery of Edinburgh University, President General of the Bermuda Industrial Union, President of the Progressive Bermuda League and Member of Parliament for St. George's, hereby declare that from henceforth I shall be known as Mazumbo." He gave as explanation: "The name Gordon, which I inherited, reminds me very painfully that some Scotsman in some other age compelled a grandmother of mine to submit to his desires. In Bermuda I am black and treated as Bermuda treats the black people.<ref>Hodgson (1988, pp. 70–71) writes: "The daily paper often underscored its contempt for coloured people by refusing to attach a title to them in any reference to them.... [Dr. Gordon's] gesture had the value of drawing the insult to the attention of many Negroes, who, from long familiarity, tended to take so many insults for granted. It was part of Dr. Gordon's overall programme of stimulating awareness on the part of the people who were so hard pressed that they had little time to think about the basis of their problems. He understood, very well, that support was gained for these political battles through starkly presented ideas, and the simple statement of the injustices which the people faced in their daily lives."</ref> So I want to be called by a name that belongs to my race and requires no prefix." He was further quoted as saying that he had taken his new name from "a famous West African chieftain, who had once been received by [[Queen Victoria]]".<ref>[http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,779223,00.html "BERMUDA: Grandpa Was a Scotsman", 21 July 1947]; cited in ''Time magazine'', 21 December 2011 (subscription required).</ref> This was a reference to a 19th-century Trinidadian lawyer called [[Emmanuel Mzumbo Lazare|Emmanuel Lazare]], popularly known as Mazumbo (or Mzumbo) Lazare, about whom Maureen Warner-Lewis has written: "although born in the Antilles, Lazare appropriated, or condoned the use of, an overtly African designation. The name was a symbol of his identification with black people and the poor. He was a defender of their rights, joined the [[Pan-African]] Association founded in 1901 in England by fellow Trinidadian [[Henry Sylvester Williams]], and became a moving spirit behind democratic political reforms at the turn of the twentieth century." This characterisation of Mazumbo Lazare is additional evidence for Gordon's motivation in associating himself with the name.<ref>Maureen Warner-Lewis, ''Central Africa in the Caribbean: Transcending time, Transforming Cultures''. Kingston, Jamaica: University of the West Indies Press, 2003; p. 80.</ref>
===Personality in Parliament=== As a Member of the Colonial Parliament (MCP), Gordon was a fiery and sometimes controversial orator. After the death in July 1948 of the Speaker of the House of Assembly Sir [[Reginald Conyers]] (who in his will left money for the Port Royal School in [[Hamilton, Bermuda|Hamilton]], providing it was "used for the education of white children"), Gordon told a public meeting that he had only attended Conyers' funeral to "make sure he was put in the hole".<ref name=BermudaBiogs /> According to Hodgson, Gordon's "dramatic personality, his drive, and his unabashed theatricals had done what no one else either could do, or chose to do. He had alerted the Negro masses, he had given expression to their unvoiced despair and anger, often his words had given shape and form to emotions which they themselves could hardly define."<ref>Hodgson (1988), p. 124.</ref>
===Bermuda Workers' Association (BWA)=== Championing the rights of black and working-class Bermudians, Gordon was asked to become president of the Bermuda Workers' Association (BWA) in 1944, which fought for trade union rights and was committed to the removal of segregation and the adoption of universal adult suffrage. Membership of the BWA had by then dwindled to 200 but under Gordon's vigorous leadership it increased to 5,000 in 1945.<ref name=Zuill>W. S. Zuill, ''The Story of Bermuda and Her People'' (1973), Macmillan Caribbean, 2nd revised edition 1983, p. 200.</ref> In 1946, he began his campaign to petition for social and constitutional change, and in that year the Legislature passed Bermuda's first Trade Union and Disputes Act,<ref name=Zuill /> which was designed to curb the fledgling BWA, making it illegal for a union to have a newspaper or operate a business.<ref name=BermudaBiogs /> Gordon took the lead in the subsequent establishment that year of the [[Bermuda Industrial Union]] (BIU),<ref name="Robert J 2004, pp. 101-02">Robert J. Alexander with Eldon M. Parker, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fCmTbz1XdMwC&pg=PA101&lpg=PA101&dq=edgar+fitzgerald+gordon+bermuda&source=bl&ots=zKXnuyJ0vW&sig=eYGBI6eOaSGYDvQ2hGdK-ZULo0E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFYQ6AEwDGoVChMI98HqwMnSxgIV0ArbCh2YJA8r#v=onepage&q=edgar%20fitzgerald%20gordon%20bermuda&f=false ''A History of Organized Labor in the English-Speaking West Indies''], Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004, pp. 101–02.</ref><ref name="biuhistory.bm">[http://rjones8.wix.com/biuhistory#!events-in-history "From BWA to BIU"], BIU History.</ref> and the BWA for the time being continued as its political arm.<ref name=BermudaBiogs />
===Petition to British Colonial Office=== During an extended visit to England from December 1946 to March 1947, Gordon presented a petition containing over 5,000 signatures<ref>[http://www.mtec.bm/portal/server.pt/gateway/PTARGS_0_0_813_0_0_43/http;/ptpublisher.gov.bm;7087/publishedcontent/publish/gov__top_level__org__house_/government/gov___history/articles/1900s.html?qid=78569854&rank=9 Government of Bermuda website.]</ref> to the British [[Secretary of State for the Colonies|Colonial Secretary]] from the BWA outlining various concerns, including the limited franchise, segregation, and restricted occupational opportunities.<ref name=BdaFranchise>[http://www.elections.gov.bm/~electb/images/bermuda_franchise.pdf "1946 – Dr. E. F. Gordon delivers Bermuda Workers’ Association Petition to the Colonial Office in Great Britain"], The Evolution of Bermuda's Franchise, compiled by James E. Smith. Parliamentary Registry.</ref><ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20150909/COMMENT01/150909742 "When the times they were a-changin’"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 9 September 2015.</ref> Only seven per cent of the population could vote, and (as Meredith Ebbin notes) there were more votes cast than actual voters because a property owner could vote in every parish where he owned land. It was a system that gave "the monied classes a distinct and definite control over the election results", Gordon said, pointing out that while the UK and its dependencies had undertaken voting reforms, Bermuda had operated under the same system since 1620.<ref>Meredith Ebbin, [http://bermudasun.bm/Content/OPINION/Opinion/Article/To-vote-or-not-to-vote--it-was-not-always-an-option/4/135/62296 "To vote or not to vote: it was not always an option"], ''BDA Sun'', 14 December 2012.</ref>
The matter was debated in the [[British Parliament]], which while condemning many of the practices highlighted in the petition refused Dr. Gordon's request for a [[Royal Commission]] to investigate social, political and economic conditions on the island. The Colonial Secretary subsequently issued a document (Command Paper 7093), sent to the Governor, Admiral Sir [[Ralph Leatham]], strongly recommending positive and progressive changes to the colony's discriminatory laws.<ref name="Bernews Profile">[http://bernews.com/2011/04/national-hero-dr-e-f-gordon/ National Hero Profile: Dr. E. F. Gordon], Bernews, 29 April 2011.</ref><ref name=BdaFranchise /><ref>[http://www.parliament.bm/Significant_Events_in_Bermuda_and_Bermuda_Parliament.aspx "Significant Events in Bermuda"], Bermuda Parliament.</ref> A Joint Committee of the Bermuda Legislative Council and House of Assembly was formed to study the matter; however, its report in April 1948 recommended against changing the colony's [[Jim Crow]] laws,<ref name=High /> holding that "the early adoption of adult franchise would be prejudicial to the best interests of Bermuda".<ref name="Bernews Profile" /> (It would not be until 1959 that segregation ended, with the BIU playing a key role in the civil disobedience that brought about the change.)<ref name=High>Steven High, [https://books.google.com/books?id=1abFAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=%22+dr+e.f.+gordon%22&source=bl&ots=W31gAwyC2_&sig=Xjvcw-s975H1bYNNphg7kw5WKAg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=y0ofVM-cAcLvaPzegMAF&ved=0CKoBEOgBMB8#v=onepage&q=%22%20dr%20e.f.%20gordon%22&f=false ''Base Colonies in the Western Hemisphere, 1940–1967''], Palgrave Macmillan, 2008, pp. 133–34.</ref>
At the 1948 election Gordon lost his House of Assembly seat – a setback attributable to his preoccupation with a dock workers' dispute that year, which had limited the time he could devote to his Parliamentary duties – but he was re-elected in 1953.<ref name="Bernews Profile" />
===Queen's visit to Bermuda=== In November 1953, when the newly crowned [[Queen Elizabeth II]] made Bermuda the first (24-hour) stop in her tour of [[the Commonwealth]],<ref name="Bermuda Online" /> Gordon learned that of more than 1,000 guests to be invited to a Government House garden party in her honour only 60 were black, and that not a single black Bermudian had been asked to attend the official state dinner.<ref name="Bernews Profile" /> With the intention of focusing world attention on Bermuda's racially stratified society, Gordon passed this news to the British press and [[Reuters]] reported the resultant angry protests from the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' and the ''[[Daily Herald (UK newspaper)|Daily Herald]]''. In its editorial the ''Herald'' stated: "Perhaps others may benefit from this instance of gross ill manners. It is time everyone from Governors downwards grasped the facts about this British Commonwealth. Within its frontiers coloured people outnumber whites by more than eight to one. One of the moral pledges by which it is held together is that the colour bar should be utterly destroyed as speedily as possible...."<ref name="Bernews Profile" /> As Bernews notes: "The Queen set foot in Bermuda the day the story broke. She was photographed that same afternoon meeting a broadly smiling, tail-coated Dr. Gordon in St. George’s."<ref name="Bernews Profile" />
==Cricket== Keenly interested in cricket, Gordon believed that Bermuda would benefit by closer contact with the islands of the [[West Indies]], which were then gaining ascendancy in [[Test cricket]]. He championed the Bermudian cricketer [[Alma Hunt]], who in 1933 went to Trinidad to take part in the trial games from which would be selected the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies team]] for the Test series in England that summer. Although proving himself both on and off the field, Hunt was not eventually given a place.<ref>Ira Philip, ''Freedom Fighters (From Monk To Mazumbo)'', London: Akira Press, 1987, p. 144.</ref> Gordon pointed out that Hunt's status would have been more assured had there been an official body to deal with finance and represent him, and advocated for a [[Bermuda Cricket Board]] of Control, which was eventually formed in 1938. He was instrumental in bringing about the first ever West Indian cricket tour to Bermuda in 1939, which was headed by Trinidadian [[Ben Sealey]].<ref>Ira Philip, in ''Freedom Fighters'' (1987), pp. 152–58, quotes a letter dated 20 October 1953 from Gordon to the ''Mid-Ocean News'', detailing Gordon's role in the sequence of events.</ref>
==Family life== Gordon and his Dominica-born<ref>Burgess, [http://www.bermuda.com/articles/share/2008/february/black-history-month-saluting-our-heroes-(4).aspx Black history month: Saluting our heroes. Dr. E. F. Gordon – one of the key figures in BDA's history"], Bermuda.com, 27 February 2008.</ref> wife Clara, who joined him in Bermuda, had six children: Barbara, Joyce, Evelyn, Marjorie (mother of [[BBC]] broadcaster [[Moira Stuart]]),<ref>[http://darrensylvester.beep.com/files/newsletter-synopsisofmoirastuartnsfamilytree_doc.pdf "''Who Do You Think You Are?''], Darren Sylvester reports on the [[BBC Two]] television series where the well known BBC newsreader, Moira Stuart, attempts to go back to her roots and research her family history (programme shown on 16 November 2004)".</ref> Edgar (familiarly called Teddy, and later known as Hakim),<ref>Ira Philip, ''Hakim: Son of Mazumbo: The Extraordinary Life of Hakim Gordon'', The Writers' Machine, 1995, 24 pp.</ref><ref>Quito Swan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5XzGAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA217&lpg=PA217&dq=%22e.+f.+gordon%22&source=bl&ots=bOkTPyx-JQ&sig=IaWAW1MJbdrdzgbKUw6cJeoW2F8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XxyZUrX3FsSjhge2voCIDg&ved=0CN8BEOgBMCE#v=onepage&q=%22e.%20f.%20gordon%22&f=false ''Black Power in Bermuda: The Struggle for Decolonization''], Palgrave Macmillan, 2010; note 28, p. 217.</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/whodoyouthinkyouare/past-stories/moira-stuart.shtml "Moira Stuart, Past Stories – ''Who Do You Think You Are?'', BBC One.]</ref> and Kenneth (who was born in Bermuda in 1927).<ref>[http://bernews.com/2013/11/dr-e-f-gordons-son-ken-gordon-dies-at-86/ "Dr E.F. Gordon’s Son Ken Gordon Dies At 86"], Bernews, 7 November 2013.</ref><ref>Owain Johnston-Barnes, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20131107/NEWS/131109796 "Musician son of national hero Dr EF Gordon dies at 86"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 7 November 2013.</ref> Clara would organise cultural gatherings, including musical soirees, at their home.<ref name=BermudaBiogs />
By a subsequent relationship Gordon had other children;<ref>Raymond Hainey, [http://www.bdasun.com/Content/NEWS/News/Article/Mother-of-our-first-female-Premier-dies-at-88/24/270/66923 "Mother of our first female Premier dies at 88"], ''Bermuda Sun'', 29 May 2013.</ref> his last child [[Pamela F. Gordon]], born six months after her father's death, would become Bermuda's youngest and first female premier in March 1997 when she replaced David Saul as leader of the [[United Bermuda Party]] until that party was defeated for the first time in a general election, in November 1998.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/pamela-gordon Gale Encyclopedia of Biography: Pamela Gordon]</ref><ref>[http://bernews.com/bermuda-profiles/pamela-gordon/ Pamela Gordon biography], Bernews.</ref><ref>Rosemary Jones (2011), [http://www.moed.bm/Documents/Teachers%20Resource.pdf Chapter 20: Into the Future], ''Bermuda: Five Centuries''.</ref> Another daughter is MP Patricia Gordon-Pamplin, who having served in various ministerial positions in the [[One Bermuda Alliance|OBA]] Cabinet<ref name=Hero>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110621/NEWS01/706219997/0/sport03 "Three heroes who ‘made Bermuda a better place'"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 21 June 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.oba.bm/index.php/your-candidates/list/111-patricia-gordon-pamplin Biography of Patricia Gordon-Pamplin, JP MP], One Bermuda Alliance.</ref><ref>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20110626/ISLAND09/706259959/-1&source=RSS "A fitting climax to a busy weekend"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 26 June 2011.</ref><ref>[http://dccaribbeanbusinessdirectory.wordpress.com/2013/03/11/ "Dame Pamela Gordon-Banks"], Influential Caribbean Women – Part 9, 11 March 2013.</ref> was announced as OBA interim leader after the change of government in July 2017.<ref>[http://bernews.com/2017/07/oba-interim-leader-deputy-leader-announced/ "OBA Interim Leader: Patricia Gordon-Pamplin"], 21 July 2017.</ref><ref>Jonathan Bell, [http://www.royalgazette.com/politics/article/20170722/gordon-pamplin-now-interim-leader-of-oba "Gordon-Pamplin now interim leader of OBA"], ''Royal Gazette'', 22 July 2017.</ref><ref>CMC, [http://wiredja.com/news/politics/bermuda-trade-union-pioneer-s-daughter-is-new-oba-interim-leader "Bermuda | Trade Union Pioneer's Daughter Is New OBA Interim Leader"], ''Wired Ja Online News'', 23 July 2017.</ref>
==Death== Dr Gordon died in Bermuda at King Edward VII Memorial Hospital, following a heart attack at the age of 60, on 20 April 1955. Two days later thousands of people turned out for his funeral service at St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Hamilton and burial at Calvary Cemetery, [[Devonshire Parish]].<ref>Ira Philip, ''Freedom Fighters'' (1987), p. 240.</ref><ref name=Philip /> According to reports, "Many of Bermuda's blacks wept at his graveside. That they had a better future was in very large part due to his tireless efforts on their behalf over more than two decades."<ref name="Bermuda Online">Keith Archibald Forbes, [http://www.bermuda-online.org/history1952-1999.htm "Bermuda's History from 1952 to 1999"], Bermuda Online.</ref>
==Legacy and honours== * The [[Progressive Labour Party (Bermuda)|Progressive Labour Party]] was formed in 1963 as the political arm of the labour movement originally organised and energised by Gordon (some of the party's founders describing themselves as "Gordonites").<ref name="Bernews Profile" /> * On 1 May 2000, a commemorative pack of postage stamps was issued honouring Dr Gordon as one of three "Pioneers of Progress" – the others being [[Henry Tucker (Bermudian politician)|Sir Henry James Tucker]] and women's suffragist [[Gladys Misick Morrell]] (1888–1969) – who made a significant and lasting contribution to Bermudian society.<ref>[http://www.gov.bm/portal/server.pt/gateway/PTARGS_0_0_4768_0_0_43/http;/ptpublisher.gov.bm;7087/publishedcontent/publish/ministry_of_finance/bermuda_post_office/philatelic_items/articles/presentation__pack_2000.html Presentation Pack 2000 – Pioneers of Progress.]</ref><ref>[http://www.stampworld.com/en/stamps/Bermuda/Postage%20stamps/?year=2000 "Bermuda – Pioneers of progress"], Stamp World.</ref> * Also in 2000, a ward of King Edward VII Memorial Hospital in [[Paget Parish]] was renamed the "Dr. E. F. Gordon Ward" after him.<ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20000908/NEWS/309089961 "Ward named for Dr. Gordon"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 8 September 2000.</ref><ref>[http://cdm15212.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p16347coll2/id/5528 "Mazumbo recognized by Hospital!" (captioned photographs)], ''The Workers Voice'' (Hamilton, Bermuda), Vol. 26, No. 1, 8 September 2000.</ref> * The Dr E.F. Gordon Memorial Hall at the Bermuda Industrial Union building is named after him,<ref name=Philip>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110319/ISLAND09/703199983&template=printart "'Our Lady of Labour' laid to rest today"], ''The Royal Gazette.</ref> as is Dr E.F. Gordon Square on Dundonald Street.<ref>Keith Archibald Forbes, [http://www.bermuda-online.org/history2007Sept11toDecember31.htm "Bermuda's History 2007 September 11 to December 31"], Bermuda Online.</ref><ref>[http://www.elbowbeachcycles.com/heritage-walk-hamilton/ Heritage Walk, Hamilton.]</ref> * An annual Dr E. F. Gordon Memorial Lecture was initiated by educator and author Dale Butler.<ref>[http://plp.bm/leadership/mps/25 "Dale D. Butler, JP, MP"], PLP website.</ref> * On Bermuda's National Heroes Day in June 2011, Dr Gordon was hailed – alongside Dr. Pauulu Kamarakafego (Dr. Roosevelt Browne) and [[Henry Tucker (Bermudian politician)|Sir Henry "Jack" Tucker]] – as one of the architects of modern Bermuda.<ref>[http://bernews.com/2011/04/three-new-national-heroes-to-be-honoured/ "Three New National Heroes To Be Honoured"], Bernews, 28 April 2011.</ref><ref>Jonathan Bell, [http://onebda.com/opinion/49-new-national-heroes "UBP salutes new national heroes"], One BDA.</ref><ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/section/island11 Bermuda's National Heroes], 16 June 2011.</ref> In the words of one columnist in Bermuda's ''Royal Gazette'' newspaper: "The most challenging times cry out for great leaders who move people and move society forward. The United States had [[Franklin Roosevelt]] and Dr [[Martin Luther King]]. We had Dr EF Gordon."<ref>Walton Brown, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120329/COLUMN02/703299957 "The traits of good leadership"], The Royal Gazette Online, 29 March 2012.</ref> * On the launch of a City of Hamilton Walkway of History, a plaque was placed at "Beulah", Gordon's former home<ref>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120929/ISLAND09/709299951 "Personal memories of Dick Richards"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 29 September 2012.</ref> – one of 25 such plaques placed at sites and buildings of historical and architectural significance.<ref>[http://www.bermudabiographies.bm/Archive/index-oct09.html "Hamilton launches Walkway of History"], Bermuda Biographies.</ref> * A portrait of Gordon is one of 80 painted by Esther Dai for display at the Historic Museum in Bermuda.<ref>Amanda Dale, [http://bermudasun.bm/Content/Default/Homepage-Article-Rotator/Article/Family-donates-portraits-of-black-Bermudians/-3/1288/52368 "Family donates portraits of black Bermudians"], ''Bermuda Sun'', 1 June 2011.</ref> * On 2 February 2015 a mural featuring a portrait of Gordon, as well as the slogan "United we stand, divided we fall", was installed at the Bermuda Industrial Union (BIU) headquarters by The Chewstick Foundation as part of their Community Art Program, honouring him as an icon in the history of the BIU and the evolution of Bermuda’s political and social growth.<ref>[http://bernews.com/2015/02/mural/ "Chewstick Installs Dr. E.F. Gordon Mural At BIU"], ''Bernews'', 3 February 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.chewstick.org/blog/page/7/ "Chewstick Community Art Program Creates Bermuda Flag Mural"], Chewstick Foundation, 16 December 2015.</ref> * On 20 March 2015, a celebration of the 120th anniversary of the birth of Dr. E. F Gordon was held in front of City Hall in Hamilton, hosted by Imagine Bermuda with the Department of Community and Cultural Affairs and the Chewstick Foundation.<ref>[http://bernews.com/2015/03/dr-e-f-gordon-national-hero-imagine-bermuda/ "Imagine Bermuda To Celebrate Dr E.F. Gordon"], ''Bernews'', 18 March 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20150317/NEWS/150319714 "Dr Gordon’s 120th birthday to be celebrated"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 18 March 2015.</ref><ref>[http://bernews.com/2015/03/photos-video-dr-ef-gordon-remembered/ "Photos & Video: Dr. E.F. Gordon Remembered"], ''Bernews'', 21 March 2015.</ref> * In October 2016 Gordon was honoured with the Peace & Social Justice Award 2016 by the Roman Catholic Church of Bermuda,<ref name=PSJA /><ref>Owain Johnston-Barnes, [http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20161025/e-f-gordon-to-be-honoured-by-church&template=mobileart "E. F. Gordon to be honoured by church"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 27 October 2016.</ref> for his "sterling contributions as the father of trade unionism and for championing the rights of Bermudian workers and black Bermudians generally".<ref>Ira Philip, [http://www.royalgazette.com/lifestyle/article/20161105/championing-rights-of-black-bermudians "Championing the rights of black Bermudians"], ''The Royal Gazette'', 5 November 2016.</ref>

The '''exclusion principle''' is a [[Philosophy|philosophical]] principle that states:
:If an [[event (philosophy)|event]] ''e'' [[causality|causes]] event ''e*'', then there is no event ''e#'' such that ''e#'' is [[supervenience|non-supervenient]] on ''e'' and ''e#'' causes ''e*''.
==In physicalism== {{Main|physicalism}} The exclusion principle is most commonly applied when one poses this scenario; One usually considers that the desire to lift one’s arm as a mental event, and the lifting on one's arm, a physical event. According to the exclusion principle, there must be no event that does not supervene on ''e'' while causing ''e*''. To show this better, substitute "''the desire to lift one's arm''" for "''e''", and "''one to lift their arm''" for "''e*''".
:If ''the desire to lift one's arm'' causes ''one to lift their arm'', then there is no event such that it is non-supervenient on ''the desire to lift one's arm'' and it causes ''one to lift their arm''.
This is interpreted as meaning that mental events supervene upon the physical. However, some philosophers do not accept this principle, and accept [[epiphenomenalism]], which states that mental events are caused by physical events, but physical events are not caused by mental events (called ''causal impotence''). However, If ''e#'' does not cause ''e'', then there is no way to verify that ''e*'' exists. Yet, this debate has not been settled in the philosophical community.
==External links== * [http://www.pupress.princeton.edu/chapters/s7971.html Princeton University Press] * [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/physicalism/#15 Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]

''Female:Pressure'' is an international network of female, [[transgender]] and [[non-binary]] artists in the fields of electronic music and digital arts founded by [[Susanne Kirchmayr|Electric Indigo]] in 1998 : from musicians, composers and DJs to visual artists, cultural workers and researchers. A worldwide resource of talent that can be searched after criteria like location, profession, style or name. "Why are there so few women active in the electronic music scene?" - each one of us has heard this question a thousand times... Here is the answer: It's not our number, it's about how and if we are recognized!
It was founded as a information resource and network for improving communication and representation of its members. It is notable for raising the profile of women and their work, including through festivals and media campaigns.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thewire.co.uk/news/26275/female_pressure-inaugurating-perspectives-festival-for-female-musicians|title=Female: Pressure inaugurating Perspectives festival for female musicians — The Wire|work=The Wire Magazine — Adventures In Modern Music|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pop-kultur.berlin/en/modules/female-pressure-panel-sky-deep-marlene-engel-christine-kakaire/|title=Female Pressure Panel at Pop-Kultur Festival 2017 in Berlin|work=Pop Kultur|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.electronicbeats.net/femalepressure-promoter-weighs-female-lineups/|title=A female:pressure Promoter Weighs In On All-Female Lineups|last=|first=|date=|website=Electronic Beats|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://loop.ableton.com/2015/participants/femalepressure/|title=female:pressure|website=loop.ableton.com|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/superstar-djs/a-41298236|title=Superstar DJs from Germany: A Global Success Story {{!}} Documentary & Report: Watch DW-videos online for free {{!}} DW {{!}} 16.11.2017|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.electronicbeats.net/the-feed/study-confirms-theres-still-a-gender-gap-in-festival-bookings/|title=Study Confirms: There’s Still A Gender Gap In Festival Bookings – Telekom Electronic Beats|last=Telekom|work=Telekom Electronic Beats|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.electronicbeats.net/the-feed/someone-made-a-database-of-female-and-non-binary-artists/|title=Someone Made A Database Of Female And Non-Binary Artists – Telekom Electronic Beats|last=Telekom|work=Telekom Electronic Beats|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://djmag.com/news/we-lost-ourselves-heady-techno-emika-and-dj-red-berlin|title=We lost ourselves to heady techno with Emika and DJ Red in Berlin|date=2017-01-31|work=DJMag.com|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/new-tumblr-documents-women-and-their-music-gear-5436612|title=New Tumblr Documents Women and Their Music Gear|last=Ohanesian|first=Liz|date=2015-03-18|work=L.A. Weekly|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref>
Since 2013, ''female:pressure'' biennially publishes the ''[https://femalepressure.wordpress.com/facts/facts-2017-results/ Facts Survey]'', a data ascertainment to survey the gender ratio of artists performing at important international electronic music festivals and in the electronic music scene.

[[Spanish language|Spanish]] |leader_title1 = [[Executive Director]] |leader_name1 = {{flagicon|Canada}} [http://www.maharaj.org/welcome.shtml Akaash Maharaj] |leader_title2 = [[Chairman|Board Chair]] |leader_name2 = {{flagicon|Mexico}} [http://www.garciacervantes.com/ Ricardo Cervantes] |established_event1 = {{Nowrap|GOPAC Charter signed}} |established_date1 = {{Start date|2002|10|06|df=yes}} |established_event2 = Entry into force of Charter |established_date2 = {{Start date|2003|01|01|df=yes}} |official_website = {{URL|http://www.gopacnetwork.org/|gopacnetwork.org}} }} The '''Global Organization of Parliamentarians Against Corruption''' ('''GOPAC'''; [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: المنظمة العالمية للبرلمانيين ضد الفساد; [[French language|French]]: ''Organisation mondiale des parlementaires contre la corruption''; [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: "Organización Mundialde Parlamentarios Contra la Corrupción") is an [[International nongovernmental organization]] made up of parliamentarians from across the world, working together to combat corruption, strengthen good government, and uphold the rule of law. Based in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], GOPAC has fifty-two national chapters in five continental associations. GOPAC supports its members through original research, global [[anti‑corruption]] capacity building, and international peer support.{{cite web|title=GOPAC Network|url=http://www.gopacnetwork.org/|publisher=Global Organization of Parliamentarians Against Corruption|accessdate=7 March 2013}} GOPAC seeks to achieve ethical and accountable governance throughout the world, through effective anti-corruption mechanisms and co-operation between parliamentarians, government leaders, and civil society. ==History== GOPAC was founded in October 2002 as a result of a Global Conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada which brought together approximately 170 parliamentarians and 400 observers who were part of the international leadership in the fight against political corruption and for good governance. As it has grown, GOPAC has formed a web of partnerships with other international institutions, including the [[United Nations Convention against Corruption]], the [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]], the [[World Bank]], and [[Transparency International]]. ==Organization== GOPAC works internationally, and is present on every populated continent of the world. It operates in four official languages: [[Arabic language|Arabic]]; [[English language|English]]; [[French language|French]]; and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. ===Membership=== Individual membership in GOPAC is open to current and former democratically-elected legislators. There are also National Chapters in fifty-two countries, grouped into six continental regions: Africa; Latin America; North America; Oceania; South Asia; and Southeast Asia. Individual legislators may be members of GOPAC even if there is no national chapter in their countries. Similarly, national chapters can be members of GOPAC even if their continent has not formed a continental association. ===Global Task Forces=== GOPAC has five thematic Global Task Forces (GTFs): Anti-Money Laundering; Parliamentary Ethics and Conduct; Parliamentary Oversight; Participation of Society, and the United Nations Convention Against Corruption; and its Women in Parliament Network. ===Global Conference=== Every two years, GOPAC convenes a Global Conference to act as an international focus for parliamentarians from across the world to set the international agenda, and to collaborate in fighting political corruption. The 2013 Global Conference was held in Manila, Philippines. ==External links== * [http://www.gopacnetwork.org/ Official website] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Anti-corruption agencies]] [[Category:International political organizations]] [[Category:Anti-corruption non-governmental organizations]] [[Category:Accountability]] [[Category:International organizations based in Canada]]

'''Greenprinting''' relates to the [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]] of land. Greenprinting is the creation of conservation scenarios that help communities make informed conservation decisions.
Greenprinting can galvanize public support and encourage partners to work toward common conservation goals. Greenprinting often involves use of state-of-the-art maps and models created with [[Geographic Information System]] ([[GIS]]) software that combines layers of spatial and [[demographic]] information to guide [[growth management]] efforts.

{{Tone|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Heather Dewey-Hagborg |image=DNA Spoofing - 2.jpg |caption=Heather Dewey-Hagborg (photo from her 2013 project ''DNA Spoofing'') | birth_date = June 4, 1982 | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | residence = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Information artist | alma_mater = New York University | notable works = Stranger Visions | website = http://deweyhagborg.com | module = {{Listen |embed=yes| filename = Dewey-Hagborg.ogg| title = Heather Dewey-Hagborg Voice| type = speech| description = recorded in August 2014}} }}
'''Heather Dewey-Hagborg''' (born June 4, 1982, [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]) is an information artist and [[Do-it-yourself biology|bio-hacker]].<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> She is most noted for her project [[#Stranger Visions|''Stranger Visions'']]: a series of portraits created from [[DNA]] she recovered from discarded items, such as hair, cigarettes and chewing gum while living in [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> She sequenced the DNA at the Brooklyn open [[biotechnology]] laboratory, [[Genspace]].<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Wilson Center"/> From the extracted DNA, she determined gender, ethnicity and other factors and then used face-generating software and a [[3D printer]] to create a speculative, algorithmically determined 3D portrait. While critical of technology and surveillance, her work has been found disturbing by some critics.<ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/tech/innovation/dna-face-sculptures/ Natalie Angley, "Artist creates faces from DNA left in public"], CNN.com, September 4, 2013.</ref>
==Education== [[File:Spurious Memories.jpg|thumb|''Spurious Memories'' (2007)]] Dewey-Hagborg is an information and bio artist whose works explore the intersection between art and science.<ref name="Colanduno, D.">{{cite web|last1=Colanduno|first1=Derek|authorlink=Derek Colanduno|title=Pieces of You #223|url=http://www.skepticality.com/piecesofyou|website=Skepticality|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=December 31, 2013}}</ref> As a student in the Information Arts program at [[Bennington College]],<ref name="Wilkinson, A.">{{cite journal|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Alec|title=Mask Crusader|journal=New Yorker|date=July 1, 2013|volume=89|issue=19|pages=22–23|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/07/01/mask-crusader|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref> she participated in computer science classes, which laid the groundwork for the science-based artwork she would later envision using [[algorithms]], [[electronics]], and [[computer programming]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She earned a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in 2003.
Dewey-Hagborg continued refining her work as an artist and computer programmer, studying [[artificial intelligence]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> while obtaining a Master of Professional Studies (M.P.S.) in Interactive Telecommunications from [[New York University]] (NYU)<ref name="Schwendener1">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|publisher=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> in 2007. It was here she curated a robotic performance art show called ''Robots on the March!'' in March 2005, and exhibited a piece called ''Lighter than Air: an experiment in constructing an autonomous flying robot''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photosynthesis and Experiments in Sustainable Robotics|url=http://www.atasite.org/calendar/archive/index-24133.html|website=Artists' Television Access|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=March 25 – April 30, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Lighter Than Air|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJmu-AzrXH4|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref>
As a final project at NYU, Dewey-Hagborg explored the question "Can computers be creative?" in an exhibit she called Spurious Memories. She developed an autonomous face categorizing and generating software program which recognized facial components, made comparisons and adjustments, and produced unique representations of the human face through mass exposure to facial images.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Spurious Memories|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1elpx1rz_R0|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=April 16, 2011}}</ref>
After graduating from NYU, she became a doctoral candidate in electronics arts at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]]<ref name="Dawsey, J">{{cite news|last1=Dawsey|first1=Josh|title=Art emerges from DNA left behind|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324281004578352473833386586|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|issue=Eastern Edition|date=March 11, 2013|page=A19}}</ref><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A.">{{cite web|last1=Squires|first1=Acacia|title=Litterbugs beware: turning found DNA into portraits|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/12/183363361/litterbugs-beware-turning-found-dna-into-portraits|website=NPR|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rodrigo, N.">{{cite web|last1=Rodrigo|first1=Nandi|title=Faces in the Crowd, Printed in 3-D|url=http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/faces-in-the-crowd-printed-in-3-d/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|website=The New York Times Blog|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Herper, M.">{{cite news|last1=Herper|first1=Matthew|title=Artist Creates Portraits from People's DNA. Scientists Say 'That's Impossible'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2013/05/31/turning-found-dna-into-portraits-what-an-imagination|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=Forbes|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> and is expected to graduate in 2016.
Dewey-Hagborg has worked as a teaching assistant at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute,<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg>{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=CV|url=http://www.deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|website=deweyhagborg|accessdate=August 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827212543/http://deweyhagborg.com/art_resume.pdf|archivedate=August 27, 2014|df=}}</ref> an adjunct professor at NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program,<ref>{{cite web|title=Interactive Telecommunication|website=Tisch School of the Arts|publisher=New York University|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=152|year=2011–2013}}</ref> and an adjunct professor at NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.<ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/><ref name="MoMa PS1"/>
As of August 2014, Dewey-Hagborg resides in [[Chicago, Illinois]], teaching art and technology studies at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Art and Technology Studies: Faculty|url=http://www.saic.edu/profiles/faculty/heatherdewey-hagborg|website=School of the Art Institute of Chicago|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> As an educator her areas of interest include art and technology, multimedia, digital photography, research-based art and programming, and computer science.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name=Dewey-Hagborg/>
==Selected projects== ===Totem=== [[File:Heather Dewey-Hagborg Totem.jpg|thumb|''Totem'' (2010)]] Dewey-Hagborg's ''Totem'' (2010) was a site-specific multimedia sculpture characterizing her earlier work. ''Totem'', an idol, was designed to explore the implications of language and artificial intelligence using [[machine learning]] technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Event Guide July thru December 2011|url=http://issuu.com/groundsforsculpture/docs/summerfall2011|website=ISSUU.com|accessdate=August 5, 2014|page=15}}</ref> Exploiting audio surveillance techniques to eavesdrop on and record conversations at the installation site, Dewey-Hagborg wrote algorithms to then isolate word sequences and grammatical structures into commonly used units. Influenced by [[Hebbian theory]], she programmed the sculpture's computer to generate speech based on the most frequently occurring language structures in any given recording period. Over time, the least frequently elicited words or units would fade or be dropped from the sculpture's spoken vocabulary. The remaining units, stored in the sculpture's memory, were then spoken at random intervals.<ref name=Totem/>
The piece also reflected the writings of psychologist [[Julian Jaynes]]. According to Dewey-Hagborg, Jaynes theorized that an early form of human consciousness evolved as a result of hallucinated speech experienced by the Mari civilization of the [[Euphrates]]. The ancient people interpreted water trickling through a goddess statue as whispers or vocalizations from the goddess herself.<ref name=Totem/> Dewey-Hagborg saw a parallel between the "mystical and authoritative power of language in the ancient world and the force of power of technology today"<ref name="Totem">{{cite web|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Totem|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GsTu3Iv1408|website=YouTube|accessdate=August 5, 2014|date=June 28, 2010}}</ref> and, with this piece, sought to explore how technology is used to shape public opinion and behavior.
Martha Schwendener, of ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote that ''Totem'' showed promise, but, because of audio difficulties and its fragmented, randomly generated speech, the piece "failed to connect human speech, meaning, and technology in a profound fashion."<ref name="Schwendener, M.">{{cite news|last1=Schwendener|first1=Martha|title=Populism, Technology, and Interactivity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/nyregion/at-grounds-for-sculpture-works-by-james-surls-and-daniel-henderson-review.html?_r=0|accessdate=August 5, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=August 28, 2011}}</ref>
===''Stranger Visions''=== [[File:Stranger Visions-1.jpg|left|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' Portraits (2012)]] ''Stranger Visions'' (2012–2014) is a science-based, artistic exploration using DNA as a starting point for Dewey-Hagborg's lifelike, computer generated 3-D portraits.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Jenkins, M.">{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Mark|title=A 'Cyber' exhibit as timely as the news|work=Washington Post|date=September 18, 2013|page=E18}}</ref><ref name="Krulwich, R.">{{cite web|last1=Krulwich|first1=Robert|title=Artist plays detective: Can I reconstruct a face from a piece of hair?|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/2013/06/28/196307915/artist-plays-detective-can-i-reconstruct-a-face-from-a-piece-of-hair|website=NPR|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite news|title=Trafics optiques a l'heure numerique: a Creteil, l'exposition "Micro Macro" interroge notre perception du reel"|work=Le Monde|date=April 6, 2014}}</ref>
She began this project questioning how much information could be understood about a person using genetic detritus left behind by strangers in [[New York City]].<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Brodwin, E.">{{cite journal|last1=Brodwin|first1=Erin|title=New Generation of Bio-Hackers make DNA misbehave|journal=Newsweek Global|date=July 4, 2014|volume=162|issue=26|pages=1–7|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/07/04/new-generation-bio-hackers-make-dna-misbehave-256322.html|accessdate=August 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> "I was really struck by this idea that the very things that make us human – hair, skin, saliva, and fingernails – become a real liability for us as we constantly shed them in public. Anyone could come along and mine them for information."<ref name="Wang, L."/> She hoped, by producing realistic sculptures of anonymous people using clues from their DNA, to spark a debate about the use or the potential misuse of DNA profiling, privacy, and genetic surveillance.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wilson Center">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions: The DNA You Leave Behind|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/stranger-visions-the-dna-you-leave-behind|website=Wilson Center|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=June 3, 2013}}</ref><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art">{{cite journal|last1=Dewey-Hagborg|first1=Heather|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg Stranger Visions|journal=C: International Contemporary Art|date=Winter 2014|volume=120|page=57}}</ref><ref name=Passarello>{{cite news|last1=Passarello|first1=D|title=Dna smarriti, una seconda vita che si fa opera d'arte|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|date=March 17, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Stranger Visions-6.jpg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 2" based on the DNA sample from a cigarette butt collected on Myrtle Avenue in New York City, N.Y.<ref name="Gambino, M.">{{cite web|last1=Gambino|first1=Megan|title=Creepy or Cool? Portraits Derived From the DNA in Hair and Gum Found in Public Places|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/creepy-or-cool-portraits-derived-from-the-dna-in-hair-and-gum-found-in-public-places-50266864/?no-ist|website=Smithsonian|accessdate=August 18, 2014|date=May 3, 2013}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-4.jpg|thumb|Collection site for DNA Samples; Corner of Wilson Avenue and Stanhope Street in [[Bushwick, New York|Bushwick, Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-2.jpg|thumb|Gum collected, which, when analyzed by Dewey-Hagborg, revealed a male of Native American and South American descent with brown eyes.<ref name="Gambino, M."/>]] As part of her research for ''Stranger Visions'', Dewey-Hagborg took a three-week crash-course<ref name="Wang, L."/> in biotechnology at Genspace, a non-profit, community-based biotechnology laboratory in New York. She was astonished to learn how much an amateur biologist could learn about someone.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L.">{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Linda|title=Guarding Our DNA: Art project exposes the vulnerability of the genetic material we unintentionally leave behind|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=June 24, 2013|volume=91|issue=25|page=33}}</ref><ref name="Pauwels, E.">{{cite news|last1=Pauwels|first1=Eleanore|title=Leave me your DNA ... and I'll 3-D print your face|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/01/dna-art-recreate-faces|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=The Guardian|date=June 1, 2013}}</ref>
She began the process of extracting DNA from the samples she collected. The extraction involves treating a hair sample, for example, with a gel that dissolves the hair, and a primer specifically developed to help locate characteristics like eye color or gender along the [[genome]].<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B.">{{cite news|last1=Gruber|first1=Ben|title=Artist stirs privacy debate with portraits from DNA|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2013/07/02/artist-stirs-privacy-debate-with-portrai?videoId=243713123|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=Reuters|date=July 2, 2013}}</ref> Dewey-Hagborg might repeat this process up to 40 times,<ref name="Andersen, K."/> looking for genetic variants influencing traits like eye color, hair color, and racial ancestry, in order to complete a portrait.<ref name="Aldous, P.">{{cite news|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Artwork highlights legal debate over 'abandoned' DNA|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23677-artworks-highlight-legal-debate-over-abandoned-dna.html#.U-N6YUi9g7A|accessdate=August 7, 2014|work=New Scientist|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Once the DNA strands are extracted from the samples, Dewey-Hagborg then amplifies, or copies, specific regions of the genome, using a technique called [[Polymerase Chain Reaction]], or PCR, a process advanced by [[Kary Mullis]], a winner of the [[Nobel Prize]] in Chemistry (1993).<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/> These amplified regions of the genome make it possible to identifying [[single nucleotide polymorphisms]], or SNPs (pronounced "snips"),<ref name=Passarello/> which contain variables in the base pairs that give clues to a person's individual genetic make up (e.g., whether or not a person's eyes might be blue, brown or green). These results are then sent for analysis to a company for sequencing. Dewey-Hagborg used [[23andMe]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/> a DNA analysis service, for ''Stranger Visions''. [[File:Dna-SNP.svg|left|thumb|Illustration of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs)]] [[File:Stranger Visions-5.jpeg|thumb|''Stranger Visions'' portrait "Sample 3" <ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Portraits|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141003124410/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/portraits.html|archivedate=October 3, 2014|df=}}</ref>]] [[File:Stranger Visions-3.jpg|thumb|Sample collected for ''Stranger Visions'' on Myrtle Avenue, [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Samples|url=http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|website=Heather Dewey-Hagborg|accessdate=August 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013095339/http://deweyhagborg.com/strangervisions/samples.html|archivedate=October 13, 2014|df=}}</ref>]]
The genetic blueprint<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Gruber, B."/> she receives in return is a text file full of coded information identifying the unique positioning of the 4 [[nucleobase]]s [[adenine]], [[thymine]], [[cytosine]], and [[guanine]], or ATC and G, that make up the sections of the genome she is interested in.<ref name="Squires, A."/> This data is then entered into a customized computer program she wrote.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/> The program interprets the code and provides her with a list of traits, including propensity for obesity, eye color, hair color, hair curl, skin tone, freckles, and gender.<ref name="Wang, L."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/> She then takes these traits, as many as 50, and enters them into a face-generating program to configure the 3-D portraits.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Wang, L."/> Her previous experience with facial recognition algorithms gave her the ability to repurpose an existing [[facial recognition system|facial recognition program]], from [[Basel]], Switzerland.<ref name="Walters, H.">{{cite web|last1=Walters|first1=Helen|title=A Portrait from a Single Hair: The Work of Heather-Dewey Hagborg|url=http://ideas.ted.com/2013/06/20/generating-a-sculpture-from-a-hair-the-work-of-heather-dewey-hagborg/|website=Ideas.Ted.Com|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=June 20, 2013}}</ref> She reworked the program to generate faces instead of just recognizing facial features.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> The resulting model changes facial dimensions (e.g., width of the nose and mouth) and characteristics with the genetic information it receives. Before making the final 3-D print,<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg generates several different versions of the face, finally choosing the one she finds most aesthetically pleasing.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K.">{{cite web|last1=Andersen|first1=Kurt|title=Making Portraits out of DNA|url=http://www.studio360.org/story/267842-making-portraits-out-of-dna|website=Studio 360|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=February 8, 2013}}</ref>
Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's ''Stranger Visions'' question whether or not the work crosses ethical and legal boundaries.<ref name="Aldous, Peter">{{cite journal|last1=Aldous|first1=Peter|title=Who's looking through your discarded DNA?|journal=New Scientist|date=2013-06-15|volume=281|issue=2921|page=12}}</ref> They make a distinction between an artist's right to express societal concerns through artwork and the act of collecting personal, genetic information without informed consent.<ref name="Gruber, B."/> The fact that DNA samples are regularly "left behind" or abandoned does not mean those people have relinquished their interest in how that information is used.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name=Passarello/>
Some laws, like that of the [[Human Tissue Act of 2004]] in the United Kingdom, prohibit private individuals from collecting biological samples for DNA analysis.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/> What laws that exist to regulate the collection and use of DNA samples in the United States are not consistent among the states and rarely address the private sector.<ref name="Wilson Center"/> Only some states, like New York, outlaw most DNA testing without written consent.<ref name="Aldous, Peter"/> Others worry about the misuse of the information, fearing discrimination based on existing medical or mental health issues or a predisposition for disease-related illnesses or "unreasonable" searches of DNA evidence by law enforcement.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/><ref name=Passarello/><ref name="Andersen, K."/><ref name="Enserink, M.">{{cite journal|last1=Enserink|first1=Martin|title=Emerging Forensics Field May Hit Legal and Ethical Obstacles|journal=Science|date=February 18, 2011|volume=331|doi=10.1126/science.331.6019.840|pages=840|pmid=21330505}}<!--|accessdate=August 7, 2014--></ref> One scientist and one gallery, according to Dewey-Hagborg, turned down her proposal fearing the project would "cause a fright" among people.<ref name="Dawsey, J"/><ref name="Wang, L."/>
Other critics focus on the growing do-it-yourself or [[Do-it-yourself biology|biohacking]] movement. Supporters like Genspace's Ellen Jorgensen claim projects like ''Stranger Visions'' engage the public and make the new technology more accessible.<ref name="Krulwich, R."/> Detractors fear unintended or unexpected consequences from unregulated experiments conducted by D.I.Y. amateur biologists developed in non-traditional laboratory settings.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/><ref name="Aldous, P."/><ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
Still others, including Daniel MacArthur, an assistant professor at [[Harvard Medical School]], [[John D. Hawks]], an anthropologist at the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]], Michelle N. Meyer, an academic fellow at the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology & Bioethics at Harvard Medical School, and [[Arthur Caplan]], PhD, Director of the Division of Medical Ethics, N.Y.U., report that the technological capability to construct an accurate likeness of a human face based on DNA evidence is not currently available.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
Although it is possible to identify certain genetic markers linked to facial structures, scientists have yet to isolate all the genes and their variations needed to produce an accurate likeness with a computer simulation.<ref name=Passarello/> Meyer, who analyzed the data from Dewey-Hagborg's website concludes:
<blockquote>So far as I can tell, she's working with sex; ancestral groups that are usually very broad, and in any event only reflects half of the individual's DNA (from which she presumably guesses hair color and texture and bone structure); and a decent guess at eye color. There are hundreds of thousands (at least) of people who would fit these descriptions even if each of her phenotype predictions were accurate, and in many cases, one or more of the predictions are probably going to be wrong.<ref name="Herper, M."/><ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name=Passarello/></blockquote>
The environment, the probabilistic nature of interpreting the DNA data collected, and limitations of computer technology all influence the outcome.<ref name="Wilson Center"/><ref name="Colanduno, D."/> She likens her work to that of a sketch artist.<ref name="Squires, A."/> At most, her portraits bear only a vague, family resemblance to the people whose genetic information was used as a foundation for the portraits.<ref name="Wilkinson, A."/><ref name="Andersen, K."/>
===''A Becoming Resemblance''=== In the summer of 2017 Dewey-Hagborg's collaborative exhibition with transgender activist [[Chelsea E. Manning]] opened at Fridman Gallery. The exhibition was an iteration of the artist's successful and controversial ''Stranger Visions'' project.<ref name="Kobler, J.">{{cite news|last1=Kobler|first1=Jason|title=Don't Give Your DNA to Giant Genetic Databases|work=Vice|date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In the case of ''A Becoming Resemblance'', Dewey-Hagborg created a series titled ''Radical Love'', 30 3-D printed portraits of Manning, based on cheek swabs and hair clippings that Manning sent her while incarcerated for leaking classified information to WikiLeaks. While all 30 portraits were based on Manning's DNA, their variances in skin color and features presents the malleability of DNA data. The installation demonstrated how much the human genome is up for interpretation once condensed and subjectively interpreted. "<ref name="Nevins, J.">{{cite news|last1=Nevins|first1=Jake|title=A Becoming Resemblance: artist creates portraits using Chelsea Manning's DNA.|work=The Guardian|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref> ''A Becoming Resemblance'' has since traveled to numerous institutions for exhibition, including The Transmedial in Berlin<ref name="Taylor, A.">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Alan|title=Photos of the Week: Super Blue Blood Moon, Starry Night, Stratofortress|work=The Atlantic|date=May 8, 2018}}</ref> ,Fridman Gallery,<ref>https://deweyhagborg.com/bio/</ref> MU Art Space in the Netherlands,<ref>http://www.mu.nl/en/exhibitions/heather-dewey-hagborg-genomic-intimacy</ref> and the 2018 Seattle Art Fair.<ref>https://seattleartfair.com/Projects-Talks/2018/Heather-Dewey-Hagborg-and-Chelsea-E-Manning-Probab.aspx</ref>
===Delaware=== [[File:Invisible-3.tif|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] In 2013, Dewey-Hagborg was contacted by an assistant medical examiner in Delaware,<ref name="Dawsey, J"/> as a result of her work with ''Stranger Visions''. The project involved developing a portrait of an unidentified woman whose case has remained unsolved for 20 years. She agreed to be an adviser to assist with the case.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> Though the resulting portrait based on the unidentified woman's DNA could only be as accurate as existing technology allowed, leaving room for speculation, Dewey-Hagborg viewed working on the case as the only potential use for this type of face-generating technology.<ref name="Squires, A."/><ref name="Herper, M."/> "If you can add anything at all to her description, if you can increase the possibility her loved ones may find her even one little bit I think it's worth it."<ref name="Herper, M."/> Critics of Dewey-Hagborg's involvement in the Delaware case express concern for what they call "D.I.Y. forensic science" and question the role of civilians in state investigations.<ref name="Pauwels, E."/>
===''Invisible''=== [[File:Invisible-1.jpg|thumb|''Invisible'' (2014)]] Dewey-Hagborg's work with ''Stranger Visions'' and interest in issues surrounding genetic surveillance lead to the development of two products whose purpose is to eliminate DNA traces. The first, ''Erase'', is a bleaching spray that cleans surfaces (e.g., cups, silverware) of DNA evidence. The second, ''Replace'', is a spray consisting of a blend of genes designed to introduce foreign DNA evidence to the surface, therefore masking any of the original DNA remaining in that area.<ref name="Brodwin, E."/> Dewey-Hagborg views these as a "citizens' defense against the looming DNA surveillance state."<ref name="Hartnett, K.">{{cite news|last1=Hartnett|first1=Kevin|title=How to cover your DNA trail|work=Boston Globe|date=May 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Additional exhibitions and events== Dewey-Hagborg's work has been exhibited at The Monitor Digital Festival in [[Guadalajara]], Mexico,<ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> [[MoMA PS1|PS1 MoMA, Long Island City, New York]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="C: International Contemporary Art"/> the [[New York Public Library]] in New York City, the [[Science Gallery]] at [[Trinity College Dublin|Trinity College Dublin, Ireland]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Science Gallery, Dublin">{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions Sculpture, 2013: Heather Dewey-Hagborg|url=https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/growyourown/strangervisions|website=Science Gallery|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> the [[University of Technology|UTS Gallery]] in [[Sydney, Australia]],<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> the [[Jaaga|Jaaga Art and Technology Center]] in [[Bangalore|Bangalore, India]], the [[Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen|Museum Boijmans]] in [[Rotterdam, Netherlands]], and the [[Ars Electronica Center]] in [[Linz, Austria]].<ref name="Colanduno, D."/>
Dewey-Hagborg has also produced the following selected works: *''Trace Recordings: Surveillance and Identity in the 21st Century'' at the UTS Gallery, Ultimo NSW, Australia<ref name="Colanduno, D."/><ref name="Frost, A.">{{cite news|last1=Frost|first1=Andrew|title=Artists use surveillance technology to explore extent we are monitored|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2013/nov/18/trace-recordings-surveillance-identity-review|accessdate=August 14, 2014|work=The Guardian|issue=Sunday|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref> *''Cyber In Securities'', Pepco Edison Place Gallery, Washington, D.C.<ref name="Jenkins, M."/> *''Plugged In: Interactive Art in Electronic Media'', [[Grounds for Sculpture]], Domestic Arts Building, [[Hamilton Township, Mercer County, New Jersey]].<ref name="Schwendener, M."/> *''DNA and Dust'' (with Paul Hazelton), QF Gallery, [[East Hampton, New York]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Art Round Up of the Week|url=http://hamptonsarthub.com/2013/07/19/art-round-up-week-of-07-19-13|accessdate=August 14, 2014|work=Hamptons Art Hub|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref> *''Unlanguage'' (with Adriana Varella), computer interactive installation, the Poland Mediations Bienniale, Zamek Castle, Poland.<ref name="Colanduno, D."/> *''Open Circuit'', [[MoMA PS1|PS1 MoMA, Long Island City, New York]].<ref name="MoMa PS1">{{cite web|title=Saturday Sessions: Hosted by Mattew Radune, Heather Dewey-Hagborg, and Thomas Dexter Featuring Open Circuit|url=http://momaps1.org/calendar/view/270|website=MoMa PS1|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=January 29, 2011}}</ref> *''Jaaga Dhvani'', sound art, Bangalore, India<ref>{{cite web|title=Jaaga Dhvani: Space Voice|url=http://eyebeam.org/feeds/heather-dewey-hagborg/jaaga-dhvani-space-voice?page=2|website=Eyebeam|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=July 1, 2011}}</ref> *''A Becoming Resemblance'' (with [[Chelsea Manning]]), Fridman Gallery, [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=A Becoming Resemblance: artist creates portraits using Chelsea Manning's DNA |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/aug/03/chelsea-manning-hair-clippings-artist-portraits-dna|accessdate=August 3, 2017|work=The Guardian|date=August 3, 2017}}</ref>
==Selected grants and awards== *2016 [[Creative Capital]] Award<ref>{{cite web|title=Announcing the 2016 Creative Capital Awardees: $4,370,000 Committed to 46 Diverse Projects|url=https://www.creative-capital.org/news_items/view/561|website=Creative Capital|accessdate=October 5, 2017}}</ref> *2013 VIDA 15.0 Art and Artificial Life International Awards, special mention<ref>{{cite web|title=Stranger Visions: Heather Dewey-Hagborg (USA)|url=http://vida.fundaciontelefonica.com/en/projects/vida-15|website=Telefonica Fundacion|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> *2012 Artist's Residency and Jerome Foundation Grant, [[Art International Radio|Clocktower Gallery]], Manhattan, N.Y.<ref name="Clockwork Tower">{{cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg, Stranger Visions|url=http://clocktower.org/residency/heather-dewey-hagborg-stranger-visions|website=Clockwork Tower|accessdate=August 14, 2014|date=January 2, 2013}}</ref> *2012 Residency at Eyebeam<ref>{{Cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg {{!}} eyebeam.org|url=http://eyebeam.org/people/heather-dewey-hagborg|website=eyebeam.org|accessdate=2016-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Heather Dewey-Hagborg Uses DNA To Reconstruct Your Identity for Art|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/artist-heather-dewey-hagborg-uses-dna-surveillance-to-swipe-your-genetic-identity-for-art|website=Motherboard|accessdate=2016-02-01}}</ref> *2008 Artist's Residency and Grant, Sculpture Space, [[Utica, New York]].<ref name="Sculpture Space">{{cite web|title=Alumni Artists|url=http://www.sculpturespace.org/alumni-artists|website=Sculpture Space|accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref>
